Dear Brandon Hannah:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action. Please note that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract.
In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately,
please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Cassandra Thomas, LMSW

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
2

Allegation On 11/15/22, a staff member instructed youth to fight one youth.
Staff member stated the other youth would not face
consequences. Youth has not been injured.
Investigation On 11/16/2022 an in-person meeting was held Chief Administrator
(CA) at Vassar House. DHHS specialist was present also. CA
was advised of the allegations of the investigation. He reported
his intention to place Staff 1 on leave pending the outcome of the
investigation.
On 11/16/2022 an in-person meeting was held with the complaint.
DHHS specialist was present. No additional concerns were noted.
On 11/16/2022 an in-person meeting was held with Youth A at
Vassar House. DHHS specialist was also present. It should be
noted that it was difficult to understand Youth A throughout the
interview. In addition, she was unable to provide detailed
information about some of the things she was asked about. Youth
A reported she is in unit four with nine other youth. Youth A
denied having been in altercations with other youth. She reported
that she had an incident report written on her last night for going to
the hospital after feeling suicidal. She denied that she is currently
having thoughts of self-harm. Youth A reported that she is tired of
her placement and the youth that she is placed with. She reported
that the youth are always telling on her. She reported that she
was at the school yesterday and refused to leave. She reported
that Staff 1 came into the room and said something to her, but did
not recall what was said. She expressed frustration that she is
always trying to tell the staff that other kids don’t get into trouble
like she does. She stated that she gave the example of dancing.
Youth A said the youth who twerk and don't get in trouble are all
African American, yet she will get redirected for dancing. Youth A
reported that Staff 1 thought she was being a racist, but she was
not. Youth A reported that she was then restrained in the hallway
by Staff 1, Staff 2, PM and RCS1 and they tried to transport her to
the classroom but were unsuccessful. Youth A reported she did
not want to go into a classroom because she was having an issue
with another peer. Youth A denied not seeing staff intervene
when a fight happens. She also denied knowledge of staff
allowing youth to fight each other. Youth A reported that Staff 1
isn't around often due to being at home. Youth A reported
overhearing Staff 1 tell other youth that they will not get any
consequences if they fight youth. She was unable to advise of
when and where this conversation was heard.
On 12/05/2022 an in-person interview was held with Youth B at
Vassar House. DHHS specialist was also present. Youth B has
3

been at the facility for three months. She reported that she is
currently in unit four and stated Youth A used to be in her unit but
she recently switched to unit two. She reported they did not get
along well with each other. She stated Youth A does things "out
of the ordinary" such as dancing inappropriately, making
comments about African Americans and then shuts down when
they try to talk to her. She further stated Youth A fails to listen to
the staff and likes to “do her own thing”. Youth B reported that all
the youth in the unit attempted to help Youth A, but she did not
want it. Youth B recalled that she and Youth A got into a fight
regarding some missing socks. Youth B denied that Staff 1 has
ever encouraged or told them to fight Youth A or any other youth.
Sher reported that Staff 1 advised them to protect themselves if
Youth A attempted to go after them. Youth B reported that staff is
supposed to intervene if youth fight and that this does occur.
Youth B reported that the staff will intervene, stating the staff
always do this and do what they are supposed to do. She
believed everyone at the facility is treated the same by staff.
Lastly, Youth B denied seeing the staff annoyed or frustrated with
Youth A.
On 12/05/2022 an in-person interview was held with Youth C at
Vassar House. DHHS specialist was also present. Youth C has
been at the facility for two months and is currently placed in unit
four. She recalled that she used to get along well with Youth A
when they were placed in unit four together, but this changed after
Youth A got upset because some other youths were making fun of
her. She reported that she encouraged Youth A to ignore them,
but she thought she should defend her. She recalled Youth A
would do weird things like dance around the unit and threaten
other youth. She also recalled hearing Youth A make racial
comments. Youth C denied hearing staff saying that the youth
should fight Youth A or any other youth at the facility. She did
acknowledge that she has heard Staff 1 indicate "I support peer
support". Youth C reported to her that meant Staff 1 supported
youth fighting Youth A if she continues to make racial comments.
Youth C was asked how she knew this is what Staff 1 meant when
making this statement and she replied that she knows what the
saying means. Youth C recalled that Youth A and Youth B have
fought each other before but denied that Staff 1 was present when
it occurred.
On 12/05/2022 an in-person interview was held with Youth D at
Vassar House. DHHS specialist was also present. Youth D has
been at the facility since June, and she is currently placed in unit
2. Youth D confirmed being in the same unit as Youth A
4

previously. She reported they got along well and were “cool”.
She recalled Youth A and Youth B getting into a fight after one of
them was upset because the line was being held up. She
reported the staff intervened and broke up the fight right away.
She never heard the staff or youth saying anything leading up to
the altercation. Youth D reported that peer support is when a
youth will help another youth. She denied peer support is a
negative term or used in a bad way. Youth D denied hearing staff
saying youth are allowed to fight other youth or that they wouldn't
have consequences if they fought. She denied seeing staff not
intervening if an altercation took place.
On 12/05/2022 an in-person meeting was held with School Staff
1(SS1) at Vassar House. DHHS specialist was also present. She
denied hearing Staff 1 tell youth that they wouldn't receive
consequences if they fought Youth A. She also denied hearing
any staff encouraging youth to fight Youth A or any other youth at
the facility.
On 12/05/2022 an in-person meeting was held with School Staff 2
(SS2) at Vassar House. DHHS specialist was also present.
She denied ever hearing Staff 1 tell the youth they wouldn't have
consequences if they fought Youth A. She also denied hearing
any staff encourage youth to fight Youth A.
On 12/13/2022 a telephone call was attempted to Staff 1 to
discuss allegations. Staff 1 did not answer and failed to return the
call. On 03/09/2023 a video interview occurred with Staff 1 at
Tuscola County DHHS office. DHHS specialist was also present.
Staff 1 reported that she does not remember a lot of specific
information from working at Vassar in November 2022. She
denied ever encouraging youth to fight each other and reported
that if she was working and youth engaged in fighting or any other
type of behavior, she would follow protocol and redirect the
behavior. Staff 1 specifically denied ever encouraging Youth A
and Youth B to fight or witnessing them fight and failing to
respond. Staff 1 lastly denied telling youth they would not face
any consequences for fighting.
On 12/13/2022 a telephone call was held with DHHS specialist.
DHHS specialist advised that she was able to interview Staff 1 in
person at her home. She reported Staff 1 reported that peer
support is when they bunk a youth with another to help motivate
the youth. She said they would share a personal aisle and
provide support to the youth. Staff 1 also denied ever telling the
5

youth to fight Youth A or telling them they wouldn't get
consequences if they did.
On 12/15/2022 a DHHS case conference was held. DHHS
specialist advised that there would be no findings relative to the
allegations involving Staff 1 encouraging youth to fight each other.
Documents Reviewed
On 11/17/2022 a copy of the trauma assessment of Youth A was
reviewed. It indicates that Youth A is diagnosed with RAD,
receptive and expressive language disorder and ADD. She's had
previous diagnosis' of autism, mood disorder, anxiety and
intellectual disability. She has been hospitalized three times
within the last year by Huron Behavioral Health. Youth A has
been hospitalized long term at Hawthorne Center. She has a
history of being aggressive and has alleged sexual abuse several
times; however, these allegations have always been unfounded.
She has been in mental health services since she was four.
There was significant concern documented for the development,
social/family relationships, emotional/behaviors and trauma index
of Youth A. Her diagnosis' were noted as PTSD and static
encephalopathy (alcohol exposure unknown).
The incident report for the restraint that occurred on 11/15/2022
was reviewed. The report was written by the staff that were
involved in restraint and was assessed to not be consistent with
the video that was reviewed.
Administration of Wolverine Human Services confirmed the
contents of the HR file of Staff 1 via email. Staff 1 was terminated
from employment due to an inappropriate restraint on 11/15/2022
and there was no other discipline in her file.
The job description for the Youth Care Worker position was
reviewed. It documents one of the staff responsibilities as
supervising and guiding clients in a variety of daily activities, while
arranging and controlling the physical surroundings in order to
provide a healthy and safe environment.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation there was no evidence to
support non-compliance as both staff and youth interviewed deny
that the staff instructed the youth to fight each other and there was
inconsistent evidence to support that the staff stated that youth
would not face consequences if they engaged in the behavior.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160 Emergency restraint
Section (1) The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff initiated an unwarranted restraint with a youth placed in the
facility.
Investigation On 11/17/2022 an email correspondence was received from the
Chief Administrator. DHHS specialist and RTCAU specialist was
included on the email. CA indicated he was able to locate the
video footage of the restraint with Youth A. He confirmed a
restraint took place on 11/15/2022 around 10:30 a.m. He further
indicated that after reviewing the footage, management deemed
the restraint was not necessary and the staff failed to utilize the
proper techniques. As a result, CA reported that the five staff
involved were terminated immediately. He said the footage would
be saved for review. He reported the staff involved were Program
Manager (PM), Resident Care Supervisor 1(RCS1), Staff 1, Staff
3 and Staff 4. CA finally advised that the agency would be placing
themselves (Vassar House) on a placement suspension where
they will not be taking any new youth for at least thirty days.
On 11/18/2022 a notification was received for new concerns
regarding potential licensing non-compliance to be investigated.
The allegation indicated that staff initiated an unwarranted
restraint with a youth placed in the facility.
On 11/29/2022 an in-person discussion was held with the
complaint. No additional concerns were noted.
On 11/29/2022 an in-person meeting was held with DHHS
specialist at Vassar House. DHHS specialist provided and
updated regarding the involvement of law enforcement and the
need for their clearance to move forward with interviews
associated with the concerning restraint of Youth A.
On 12/13/2022 a telephone call was held with DHHS specialist.
DHHS specialist confirmed that law enforcement approval to move
forward with interviews is still pending.
Email exchanges with DHHS Specialist occurred on 01/06/2023,
01/18/2023, 01/31/2023, requesting an update regarding the
7

ability to move forward with interviews for the investigation. She
advised that law enforcement approval was still pending. On
02/28/2023 an email was sent to DHHS specialist to request an
update regarding the ability to move forward with interviews for the
investigation. She advised that law enforcement approval has
been provided and interviews can be scheduled for the
investigation.
On 03/09/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth A at
Vassar House. DHHS specialist was also present during the
interview. Youth A recalled the restraint that occurred with her at
Vassar on 1/15/2022. She recalled she was in the classroom,
and she was talking to School Staff 1 and School Staff 2 about her
problems. Youth A stated Staff 1 walked in and said she didn't like
her response and called her a racist. Youth A said she was
expressing that she feels that the white kids don't get warnings
when they do things that may get them in trouble. She stated that
she feels the African American youth get warnings, unlike her.
Youth A said she was refusing to go back to class and that she
was the only youth in the class. Youth A said the Staff 1 and
RCS1 were telling her that if she did not get up, they would
remove her from the classroom. She said Staff 1 attempted to
carry her out of the classroom and pulled the chair from
underneath her and then transported her by carrying her out.
Youth A denied that she was attempting to resist and was not
being a threat to herself or anyone else.
On 03/09/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 1 at
Tuscola County DHHS. DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 1
reported that Youth A was refusing to leave the classroom and
she was attempting to encourage her by talking to her. She
reported Youth A was sitting in a chair near a computer and she
tapped her on the shoulder to get her to walk with her. She said
when Youth A stood up on her own, she then moved the chair
right away so that Youth A couldn't sit back down. She stated this
is when Youth A dropped to the floor on her own. Staff 1 reported
that Staff 3, Staff 4 and RCS1 then moved Youth A from the
classroom but was unable to indicate what approved technique
was utilized. Staff 1 indicated that she felt Youth A should have
never been restrained because she had not done anything to
warrant a restraint.
On 03/09/2023 an in-person meeting was held with the Program
Manager (PM) at Tuscola County DHHS office. DHHS specialist
was also present. PM confirmed that she was present the day
Youth A was restrained. PM stated Youth A had been refusing to
8

leave the classroom for some time. She reported that she
recalled Youth A was laying on the floor in the classroom but was
not fighting staff nor was she saying anything. After watching parts
of the video, PM indicated that there was no reason that Youth A
should have been restrained and that staff did not intervene the
way they are trained to.
On 03/15/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2.
DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 2 reported she has
discipline in her file for failing to report an inappropriate restraint.
She confirmed being present during the incident with Youth A
back in November of 2022. She said she was in the kitchen fixing
lunch for the youth when she realized they were thirty to forty
minutes late coming to eat. She walked out of the cafeteria into
the hallway and saw Youth A laying on the floor. She described
Youth A as laying face up with her arms above her head. She
said PM, RCS1, Staff 3 and Staff 4 were standing over Youth A.
She denied staff or Youth A were saying anything to one another.
Staff 2 reported she attempted to talk to Youth A and encourage
her to get up, but she refused. Staff 2 stated she was then
directed by PM to grab Youth A’s leg. She said Youth A was just
lying on the ground and wasn't kicking or fighting with the staff.
She reported that she grabbed Youth A’s leg and Youth A kicked
her causing her to fall to the ground. She said she got up and
went back to the cafeteria. Staff 2 confirmed she is trained to
restrain the youth but noted she often isn't involved in restraints
because the youth typically listen to her. She denied she was
trained to restrain a youth who is just lying on the floor not doing
anything. She also confirmed that she felt they should have
allowed Youth A to just lay on the ground. Staff 2 said the entire
incident happened so fast and she was only following what PM
told her to do.
An attempt to interview RCS1 was unsuccessful. She failed to
show for scheduled in-person interview at Vassar House on
03/09/2023 and failed to respond to telephone calls from myself
and the DHHS specialist. RCS1 is no longer employed with
Wolverine Human Services. A written statement submitted by
RCS1 was reviewed. She wrote on 11/15/2022 at approximately
9:30 a.m. she was notified that Youth A was becoming agitated
and was in her classroom. She stated that upon arrival into the
classroom, Youth A was sitting on the floor at a workstation
ranting on about how she is the only youth who gets held
accountable at the facility and that she feels like staff are racist.
RCS1 wrote that she left out of the classroom at approximately
10:00 a.m. for a meeting and returned at approximately 11:20 a.m.
9

when she was informed that Youth A was refusing to leave the
class. RCS1 wrote that Youth A was again asked to move out of
the classroom so that her teachers could get back to what they
were supposed to be doing and Youth A did not respond and
continued to lay on the floor. RCS1 wrote that multiple
staff/teachers attempted to encourage Youth A to do the right
thing and leave out of the classroom and re-join her group in the
next class. After another ten minutes of her silence, staff made an
attempt to help Youth A and escorted her out of the classroom.
Once out the classroom, RCS1 wrote that Youth A began to use
her body weight to drop down in the classroom door area. Staff
attempted to support her body to keep her on her feet, but were
unsuccessful and Youth A lost her grip and ended up on the floor.
She wrote Youth A then began to kick and swing at staff and she
was placed in a restraint for safety. RCS1 further wrote that once
Youth A was out of the restraint, she began to lift her shirt up over
her head while lying on the floor. RCS1 wrote that she tried to pull
her shirt back down, but that Youth A pulled it up again. RCS1
wrote that after a few times of that cycle, when Youth A pulled the
shirt up, she pulled it off of her and removed the shirt. RCS1
wrote that she stood over Youth A positioning her feet on the ends
of the shirt to keep her covered as youth were passing and some
received medication. RCS1 then wrote that once the hallway was
cleared and Youth A had laid there for a period of time, she was
escorted into class. RCS1 was initially suspended and
subsequently terminated by the agency.
An attempt to interview Staff 3 was unsuccessful. He failed to
show for a confirmed in-person interview scheduled for
03/09/2022 and attempts to contact him via telephone by myself
and DHHS specialist were unsuccessful. Staff 3 was initially
suspended and subsequently terminated by the agency. A written
statement submitted by Staff 3 was reviewed. It indicated that he
was asked to assist in returning Youth A to the classroom and that
Youth A was refusing to move. Staff 3 further wrote Youth A was
kicking staff, so she was put in a restraint on the floor.
An attempt to interview Staff 4 were unsuccessful. She failed to
show for a confirmed in-person interview scheduled for
03/09/2022 and did not respond to telephone calls by myself and
DHHS specialist. Staff 4 was initially suspended and
subsequently terminated by the agency.
On 04/13/2023 a DHHS case conference was held. DHHS
specialist advised there are findings to their investigation.
10

Video footage (dated for 11/15/2022 at 9:15 am) of the incident
provided by Wolverine Human Services was reviewed which last
for approximately four hours. It began with Youth A siting in the
classroom and then progressed to her being dragged out of the
classroom by staff. Youth A is seen on the video laying on the
floor. The video does not have audio, but it does not appear that
Youth A is saying anything and is not presenting as aggressive or
combative. As Youth A is laying on the floor, RSC1, Staff 3 and
Staff 4 are seen grabbing the Youth by her legs and dragging her
out of the classroom into the hallway.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as Youth A was reported to
be restrained because she refused to leave her classroom.
Refusal to leave a classroom is not an approved reason to engage
in a restraint with youth per licensing rules. The restraint is
assessed as being unwarranted as Youth A was not presenting as
a potential threat to herself or others.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff utilized inappropriate restraint techniques with a youth.
Investigation The email sent by Chief Administrator on 11/17/2022 he indicated
that after reviewing the video footage, management deemed the
restraint was not necessary and the staff failed to utilize the proper
techniques.
On 03/09/2023 a video interview occurred with Staff 1 at Tuscola
County DHHS office. DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 1
reported she attempted to speak with Youth A about taking
accountability for her own actions which upset Youth A and Youth
A started yelling. Staff 1 recalled that Youth A was refusing to
leave the classroom and she was attempting to encourage her to
by talking to her. Youth A was sitting in a chair near a computer,
and she tapped her on the shoulder to get her to walk with her.
She said Youth A stood up on her own and she moved the chair
right away so she couldn't sit back down. She reported this is
when Youth A dropped to the floor on her own. Staff 1 reported
11

RCS1 advised her, Staff 3 and Staff 4 to “move” Youth A due to
her holding up the teacher in the classroom. Staff 1 reported they
attempted to encourage Youth A to leave the classroom and she
refused and laughed at them. She reported RCS1, Staff 3 and
Staff 4 then removed Youth A from the classroom into the hallway
by holding Youth A under the arms and Youth A was on the floor
but kicking herself out of the classroom. Staff 1 then reported
RCS1 said that Youth A needed to be placed in a team restraint,
but she wasn’t sure why. Staff 1 was unable to say what restraint
technique was used to get Youth A out of the classroom. She
further reported that when RCS1 made the decision to have Youth
A moved from the hallway back into another classroom with the
rest of the youth, staff lifted Youth A underneath her arms and
carried her into the classroom. Staff 1 denied they are trained to
carry youth from one area to another. She said she wasn't sure
why they wanted Youth A to move so bad that day, as it could
have been because she was holding up the program for other
youth. Staff 1 indicated that she felt Youth A should have never
been restrained because she had not done anything to warrant a
restraint.
On 03/09/2023 a video interview occurred with Program Manager
(PM). DHHS specialist was also present. She denied being
present for the entire incident, stating she was in and out of the
area. PM said that when she went into the classroom that day
Youth A was on the floor. She wasn't sure how long she had been
lying there and denied Youth A was saying anything. PM said she
left the area and when she returned, Youth A was in the hallway in
a restraint. PM said the staff was struggling with holding Youth
A’s feet so she assisted with the restraint. She denied knowing
why Youth A was placed in a restraint. She stated she continued
to try and motivate Youth A to get up off the floor and go to her
classroom, but she refused. PM said Youth A laid in the hallway
for a long time. She denied telling the staff to take Youth A into
the classroom. PM reported that Youth A was taken to the
classroom by RCS1, Staff3, Staff 4 and Staff 1 by carrying her.
She denied being a part of this, but noted Youth A’s arms kept
falling so she was trying to hold it up for her, but Youth A kept
fighting her, so she stopped. PM reported how Youth A was
transported to the classroom is not how they're trained to deal with
youth. After watching parts of the video, PM indicated that there
was no reason that Youth A should have been restrained and that
staff did not intervene the way they are trained to.
On 03/15/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2.
DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 2 reported she has
12

discipline in her file for failing to report an inappropriate restraint.
She confirmed being present during the incident with Youth A
back in November of 2022. She said she was in the kitchen fixing
lunch for the youth when she realized they were thirty to forty
minutes late coming to eat. She walked out of the cafeteria into
the hallway and saw Youth A laying on the floor. She described
Youth A as laying face up with her arms above her head. She
said PM, RCS1, Staff 3 and Staff 4 were standing over Youth A.
She denied staff or Youth A were saying anything to one another.
Staff 2 reported she attempted to talk to Youth A and encourage
her to get up, but she refused. Staff 2 stated she was then
directed by PM to grab Youth A’s leg. She said Youth A was just
lying on the ground and wasn't kicking or fighting with the staff.
She reported that she grabbed Youth A’s leg and Youth A kicked
her causing her to fall to the ground. She said she got up and
went back to the cafeteria. Staff 2 confirmed she is trained to
restrain the youth but noted she often isn't involved in restraints
because the youth typically listen to her. She denied she was
trained to restrain a youth who is just lying on the floor not doing
anything. She also confirmed that she felt they should have
allowed Youth A to just lay on the ground. Staff 2 said the entire
incident happened so fast and she was only following what PM
told her to do.
An attempt to interview RCS1 was unsuccessful. She failed to
show for scheduled in-person interview at Vassar House on
03/09/2023 and failed to respond to telephone calls from myself
and the DHHS specialist. RCS1 is no longer employed with
Wolverine Human Services. A written statement submitted by
RCS1 was reviewed. She wrote that on 11/15/2022 staff tried to
help Youth A and escorted her out of the classroom. Once out the
classroom, RCS1 wrote Youth A began to use her body weight to
drop down in the classroom door area. She then wrote that staff
attempted to support her body to keep her on her feet but were
unsuccessful and Youth A lost her grip and ended up on the floor.
She wrote Youth A then began to kick and swing at staff and she
was then placed in a restraint for safety. RCS1 further wrote that
once Youth A was out of the restraint, she began to lift her shirt up
over her head while lying on the floor. RCS1 wrote that she tried

The TCI behavior management policy of Wolverine Human
Services was reviewed. The policy specifically indicates that the
agency will utilize non-violent physical intervention when
necessary. Non-violent physical intervention is defined as a staff
member’s use of physical control to contain a client’s acute
physical behavior. Acute physical behavior is defined by any
behavior that is likely to result in physical injury or imminent risk of
physical harm of the client, other clients, staff members, or others.
These interventions are non-violent and are to be used in such a
manner as to not be hostile or injurious. All non-violent physical
interventions at Wolverine Human Services will follow the
principles established by the TCI curriculum. Approved
techniques for physical restraint include supine restraint and
standing restraint.
